This video was the opportunity of a lifetime. When asked if I wanted to fly in an F-16, I said "Yes please, and there are some things I'd like to study. Can we try supersonic flight at different altitudes?" I'm very grateful for this opportunity and would like to thank Flack and the rest of the US Air Force Thunderbirds. This flight took place on May 3rd, 2019. This Spatial Disorientation training is something all fighter pilots go through so they can understand how their own physiology works under these conditions.
Thank you for watching and learning with me. I always wanted to know what happened in the cockpit when a jet goes supersonic. If you think this kind of content is worthy of your support, you can become a patron at: https://www.patreon.com/smartereveryday

When my son decided to join the military he chose the Air Force. He thought that they were just waiting for him to join and he would just enlist. Well, it took about 9 months to be fully accepted and to get a Basic Training spot. Lots of mental, physical and intelligence testing. He scored high and selected to train in an intelligence role. He thought he was finally in, well, at every step of boot camp and at his training he was required to pass with high marks. If you fail boot camp you are discharged, if you fail any training you get demoted to a lower job but still remain enlisted. On a call with my son during all of this re remarked " Dad, I wish i had studied harder  in high school" He buckled down with peer pressure from the other service men and a new drive to learn and be the best. Today, I hardly recognize him as the floundering lad from his teen years, he is bigger, stronger and much smarter. The air force takes no excuses, meet the expectation or they don't need you. . I would recommend the AF to anyone who is serious about a future who is able to work hard to achieve.

And that was a really cool experiment at NASA - especially with the camera on your eyes when rotation of the chair stopped. It is a practical demonstration of sea or in general motion sickness: your eyes and inner ear try and work together. But if your eyes see a steady picture, while your ears say "motion", your body / nervous system goes haywire, you start to sweat and feel nauseaous.

That is why people who suffer a lot from this should not read while riding a car and need to get out and look at the sea and horizon on ships, to get vision and motion senses aligned (even when the weather is aweful, though of course the sight of thunderous waves frightens you even more).

It is also easier for them to drive the car, because then they initiate the changes and will be prepared to deal with the change in acceleration / motion. Which makes me wonder, how much being in control of the jet helps coping with the additional G forces from 7 to 9.

Several years ago my neighbor at the time was a SMSgt in the USAF. He took me to an air show at his base- Scott AFB, IL- about 11 miles from us. The T-Birds we’re doing a show. Sarge Nielsen gave me a personal guided tour of all the aircraft on display and at show time he got us right up next to the flight line. I’d seen the T-Birds before from a distance but to see it all up close was surreal. The pre-flight check with the pilots and their personal crews was amazing- I still get goosebumps thinking about it.  My FAVORITE maneuver was 1-4 in Diamond coming in from the east in a slow roll. Everyone’s attention was that direction. 5 came from the west right over the tarmac at about 200 ft and about .7 Mach and the burner cooking. Scared the “ya know” out of everyone including me. Prior Air Force here. ( 3C051 MOS ) '95-'99. I was stationed at Langley AFB VA working for a software development squadron and I lived in on base housing facing the flight line for my first 1.5 yrs there. I can remember some amazing aircraft coming and going, including the Thunderbirds but I'll never forget one early Saturday morning being woken up by the B-2 Stealth Bomber coming in for a landing. You could feel it in the walls of my dorm room and seeing that massive alien looking craft come in was unforgettable.

A good friend of mine, Dave, won "Airman of the Year" and was awarded a flight in an F-16. We all sat out in the smoke-pit and watch the pilot blast our buddy off, after burners roasting him straight up and out of site in seconds! After the flight, he told us he didn't remember much of the flight and ended up puking in the cockpit - he owed the pilot a case of beer. Had my buddy not thrown up during the flight, we all would have been drinking that case instead. We told Dave - Pilots never lose that bet man, don't make it. LOL

It should be emphasized that the reduction in the speed of sound with altitude isn't because of going up in altitude. It is because the speed of sound is related to the temperature, and the temperature decreases generally with altitude. In an inversion layer or in the thermosphere, however , the speed of sound can go up with altitude. And in the stratosphere, where the temperature is fairly constant, the speed of sound is just as constant with change in altitude.

My dad was in the US Airforce.  he told me about a time when a flight of jets took off and a couple of them had completely wacky airspeed readings.  turned out that some of the planes had been repainted and whoever painted them had painted over the static ports on the pitot tubes.  the guys with the the blocked ports had to be fed the speed info on the radio by the unaffected planes so they could land without stalling

I think calibrated air speed needs more explanation. Mach 1 in true airspeed might is 1225km/h at sea level and 1076km/h at 10km. For CAS the mach 1 at sea level is also 1225km/h but at 10 km it's only 680 km/h. This is because CAS is not really a speed as it is a measurement of the aircraft performance. Of course the mach number is more important if you are close to or above mach 1.

Sry for using metric instead of real aviation units. I am sure all you imperial guys can understant the discomfort of using an unfamiliar measurement system ;)

27:33 when you have the HUD and you watch it during a hard turn, your brain doesn’t get effected as if your looking out the window. An example is to keep your head straight but move your eyes from left to right, you think your moving slowly and smoothly but your not, your eye movement is lots of stops and starts and if you try it more times you will notice it even more, this is why eyes and ears are connected to balance. If your a passenger in a car or train, as it moves faster look out the side window, it’s just a blur, now blink fast and you’ll see many sharp images of what your passing…..and don’t forget, your eyes have already turned the image upside down so your brain can work out what your seeing…the marvels of the human body.

Friends and neighbors, this is why we ALL in the airline community go visit the high altitude chamber. God designed us all differently. Some of us do really well under O2 deprivation. Others  have different responses and we need to understand what to those are so we can better protect the flying public behind the cockpit door in the VERY rare but forsaken event of a decompression. We train to improve the safety of the travelling public every day. That's the connection from fighters to airlines: lack of O2 to the brain. Thanks for bringing that home Justin.

So something interesting about the F-16 control stick, it does barely move, but the movement of the stick isn't actually what controls the aircraft; its the pressure on the stick. From the story I heard, the original versions of the F-16 (I don't know if these were prototypes or the first models produced) didn't actually have a stick that moved at all, but pilots complained that it just felt too unnatural for the stick to not move at all, so they made the stick move just a tad in the later versions and they no longer had the issues. Apparently just a small amount of movement is enough to make it feel not totally unnatural, and also the human body works just as well with pressure for control as movement for control.

I would still never want to use an actual F-16 stick though, it seems super freaking weird.

The sonic boom shockwave is behind you, the jet. The way in which the fighter jet is designed is that while you can feel the pressure differential during supersonic flight, you won't hear the boom because you're traveling in front of the pressure differential. The actual boom is the release of energy from the pressure wave that passes by other objects that aren't in the supersonic envelope.

Consider this. If you could fly around the globe in one day, and you wanted to fly from equador and land in equador in 12 hrs, what direction would you go?

“…I’ll be humbled by force.” Words to live by in all areas of our lives. Unfortunately, the vast majority of people today, including myself by even saying this, do not live by this. We think we know better than the next. “Force” in this flight context is a kinetic force, but in our daily lives, “force” can be stumbling on our rear ends, embarrassment, or even hurting others. We should all live by these words and approach EVERY event in our day with only enough confidence to get us safely through it but enough humility to keep us honest. Thank you for the reminder!

21:07 reminds me of my rudimentary instrument lessons when taking my PPL. In Canada, the law requires that private pilots have basic instrument instruction, so I went up on a smokey, yet still VFR day and put on an "instrument hood" to simulate IMC. There was a time when my instructor asked me to close my eyes and tell him what direction he was turning. You feel everting, like the roll-in to all of the turns, but I could swear that we were in a climbing gentle right bank. We were actually in a steep level left turn. You can never trust your ear when you are flying on those conditions, and the notion of getting used to the forces is a major factor.

One thing most videos about both the USAF's and USN's [the Blue Angels] demonstration teams fail to mention is one minor detail about the aircraft that should make the viewer realise just how amazing the ground crews are, not just the pilots.  Yes, these are military fighter jets being used, but they are NOT the latest, newest fighter jets in use.  Sometimes the aircraft are decades old.  The latest, newest jets are being used by active combat units around the world.  Think of your car being pushed to its limits on a weekly basis for years.  How much maintenance will you need to do to keep it performing that way?  Plus, again these are NOT deployed combat units.  So, they're NOT really a priority for the latest, greatest parts.  Scrimping, scavenging and miracle working are sometimes the norm.  And, yet, neither team has ever had a show cancellation because of mechanical issues.

From my understanding training your brains reaction to pulling Gs is in a way similar to drinking alcohol. The tolerance you build up is your brains ability to stabilize the wobbly inputs your inner ear is receiving. If you drink often your brain will be able to stabilize that input more and more. And the comments she made about tolerance building and inner ear fluids effect on your senses verified my hypothesis to some degree. Every one has a personal tolerance to inner ear manipulation, but it can be built upon through experience. So pulling Gs and drinking are similar in that way.

The reason why the mach number is lower in high altitudes is, because it is dependent of the temperature, which decreases.

a = sqrt(k • R • T)
where a is the mach number,
k which is 1,4 for air,
R the specific gas constant,
and T the temperature.

Learning one’s limits is a foundational aspect of maturity and (ironically) is what allows some people to exceed a (perceived) limit. Mace addressed this when she spoke about “acquired tolerance” gained through repetition and training. We start out as children with an important and necessary deception called perception of invulnerability. As children, we walk around most of the time believing we cannot die. We have vastly unrealistic beliefs about our abilities and limits. My mother loves to tell the story of a 3-year-old me who would tell her that I could not be hit by a car while playing in the street, because I would lie on the ground and push the car in the air and make it pass over me. I truly believed this. As we age, experiences and gained knowledge begins to lessen our perception of invulnerability as reality sets in and we begin to truly learn our limits. However, most of us we never completely shed this mythological perception, and that is very important for us as a society to grow and create. People like Steve Jobs and Elon Musk have maintained a lot of their perception of invulnerability, supported and affirmed by their successes (when others tell them something is impossible). Their failures may lessen this invulnerability perception, but it doesn’t erase it (thankfully). If everyone had an exactly perfect perception of their vulnerability, far fewer would ever attempt to achieve something beyond a consensus of what the crowd says is possible. This is augmented by dreams, aspirations and necessity, but the foundation is that critical perception of invulnerability. Before Mace ever sat in a cockpit, she had some perception that she would (or might) be invulnerable to G forces that most of us cannot withstand. Her successes affirmed this perception until she trained to make it her reality. Your experience in the F-16 denied your perception of invulnerability and you gained maturity and a wonderful new attitude about approaching new experiences and interactions with other people. You are now more aware of your limits and the reality that your perception of invulnerability can be wrong and cause you to act in ways that can hurt your relationships with others and hamper your ability to succeed. That is a real key (IMHO) to succeeding in life: the constant affirmation and denial of our perception of invulnerability, which teaches us our limits, but also causes us to strive to “acquire tolerance” so we can push beyond a previous limitation to grow, create and expand our horizons.

The reason you can break the sound barrier easier at higher altitudes is because you have a lower temperature at higher altitudes. Since the speed of sound (for an ideal gas) is defined as sqrt(gamma*R*T) a lower temperature corresponds to a lower speed of sound. Therefore, you need less velocity to break the sound barrier, since M = v/a where a is the local speed of sound, and v is the velocity of the aircraft. Interesting Stuff!

To maintain some manliness Destin decided not to use the first footage of his eyes wigging out...Because that footage was taken by a group of 7 yr olds from his local park after they spun him around so many times on the merry-go-round he lost his grip (inertia and centrifugal force) which launched him a few feet away...as he regained awareness and attempted to regain his orientation all he could hear were all those kids laughing at him...He decided not to be "humbled" that way...so he visits a Physicist with an adult-sized stainless steel merry-go-round for one... well-played sir...

PS. I had a similar experience during my last semester of college (Auburn 1990) & I think I have still had the video (VHS) showing my eye's doing the same thing... but my eyes wigging out wasn't due to a merry go round...it was due to the aggressive mixing of fluids while I was doing my best MC Hammer imitations after numerous shots of Jager, Jack and a couple pitchers of PBR... I will still convince under oath the room was spinning ... That's all I remember...I passed out before tapping out...and upon awaking I too was humbled---big time...although everything was still spinning I felt a draft and noticed all I was wearing were tightie whities and some loafers (and I wear boxers)...I was able to escape from the indoor Mcdonald's play area plastic ball pit...where my "friends" had obviously left me... Geez...I'm nauseated just thinking about that...

I’m a retired USAF aircraft engine mechanic and spent most of my career on F-16s, 9.5 years at Luke AFB. In 2005 while TDY to NAS Key West i had an incentive ride in the F-16, coolest thing I ever did. I am 6’3” and the pilot that flew me was also 6’3” and even though the jet was slick (no external tanks and bomb racks) because me and the pilot are both big guys the max Gs we could get out of the jet was 8.4G. Most people have the physical capacity to do what fighter pilots do rather its the mental stress that many people cant handle. You could have dealt with the Gs if you were better prepared, and perhaps a little less cocky even if it was internalized; pilots are constantly training to deal with high G maneuvers, its mostly core and lower body work in the gym plus breathing exercises (I think you mentioned the “hick” breathing, Im sure your pilot did in your pre-flight, maybe you just didn’t think much of it.) You barely touched on whats going on in the HUD and didn’t even deal with the multiple radars, radios and weapons that fighter pilots deal with, these are where us mere mortals cant keep up with the fighter pilots...that said, they’re pretty much just regular people who get to do a real cool job.

Back in January 1990, I was working as an engineer and technical advisor for a concrete anchoring company. A structural engineer in Dallas was designing a remodel on the hangers at Nellis AFB and two of us were sent out there to perform pull tests on various anchor types and sizes, in the CMU and solid concrete, on their existing hangers.

For whatever reason, they put us on scaffolding on the flight deck side of the colonel’s (center) hanger. I guess they knew we would be breaking holes in things, and it would be a few months before those holes were fixed/covered, so that would be an area most people would never see. In addition to the Thunderbirds daily practice routine, the US was also ramping up for Dessert Shield. We spent 3 days working off that scaffolding and we saw the greatest airshow anyone could ever hope for. True story and great memory.
Excellent video....well worth a “subscribe.”  I’m a civil engineer, so statics and structural design are more in my wheel house, but I found your explanation fascinating.

My Grandad was a test pilot. He began his career in the 1920s and outlived all his contemporaries before retiring happily. Two stories come to mind. One day during the war, whilst testing engine upgrades on a spitfire over the south of England, he was engaged by a returning German fighter. Not having any ammunition loaded for test flights, he was forced to engage in a dogfight with no weaponry. He swiftly outmanoeuvred the fighter, lining himself up for the "kill". This was sufficient to send the German packing back across the channel and for him to survive! Secondly, he was the first person to successfully escape from a fixed canopy aircraft pre ejector seats. His plane had entered an uncontrolled dive, so he calmly opened the window using the crank, and dived out. They don't make 'em like they used to. Respect to all aviators. They're a breed apart.

WARNING! Carry on reading, or your soul will be taken, even if you read the word "warning"! There once was a man named Duke Hunapon. He was lazy, and very uncaring. Love the video but one aspect was not correct.  The lovely lady referred to the latent movement as the Coriolis effect.  This is not correct.  The Coriolis effect is the result of relative Linear motion in a circular motion environment.  Mathematically it is omega cross Velocity.  The concept she was referring to is better defined as a residual motion within the vestibular.

I seriously damaged my Vestibular system a few years back. I constantly have to depend on my vision, body position sensation and gravity sensation to determine which way is up. I have to walk with a cane and/or drag my hand along a wall for a tactile reference to a fixed point in space. It is very taxing to the processing power of my brain - which has to continuously recompute which way is up - with no gyros to help. This (vestibular) system also controls eye movement, which is why you had the nystagmus. When I walk, I see like an old jerky 8mm movie instead of a nice steadycam image. Seasickness is very common
.
Often, when I lose sight of visual references of the horizon or suddenly move my head, I fall over. I also get into what I call "reverberation mode" when I lose visual reference, especially in a closed in space, I start swaying around like a bird on a wire and can not stop even after regaining a visual reference. Fortunately, and this is not a joke, I drink a few shots of alcohol to get me out of that loop. When people drink alcohol, they get pretty much the same effect with their balance, coordination, and eye control I now have normally. In effect, I get anti-drunk, which steadies me up, probably by numbing my damaged system.

Science Project:
Next time you sit in that chair, try it again after a few shots. I suspect it will make a measurable difference.

Or it will make you barf.
I would also bet it would be about a 50/50 chance you will ever go flying with Flack again while sober.

Could it be that traveling at Mach speed is easier at higher altitude due to the lower volume of air? By that I mean the medium it travels through becomes less as dense thus requiring less work (mainly kinetic energy which is m*v*v/2) making it easier to travel through it. A lower volume reduces drag force and being further away from the earth, even slightly, reduces the force due to gravity. You might be lighter by an insignificant amount but that drag force I’m sure is reduced significantly.
My question to you now becomes this after seeing your video and after seeing the video called engineering with origami (truly amazing and I’m sorry if I mentioned this in more than one comment); how much more aerodynamic and possibly lighter could a plane be to reach that altitude and speed as well as be able to sustain all of those forces through the use of origami?

I love this video. I spent a military career (20 years) maintaining various USAF aircraft. But one of the most memorable moments for me was my F-16 flight. I was given the opportunity to take the controls, experience 7.1 G's (we had external tanks loaded on the wings and this was the maximum capability for that configuration), and break the sound barrier. It truly was a surreal feeling and one that tests your human ability. This happened before smart phones and GoPro cameras so I have no footage of the flight unfortunately. It was an honor to serve and a huge bonus to have that experience! God bless the USA!!! Thanks for sharing Destin, it brings back a fond memory.

Destin, I know you maybe regret tapping out, but people who haven't experienced G's don't understand how brutal they are... Especially the first time you get punched in the face by them. My first time hitting >4 G's I thought I was going to die and at 6.7 G's, only 5 mins later, I had enough. I was flying with my Squadron Commander in Pensacola, FL (in fact we were around Dauphin Island as seen in your video here) and I had to tap out before we got to the "fun stuff" so I felt sooooo weak. I definitely didn't recover in a few minutes either. I was a wreck for the rest of the 30 min flight and even through the debrief I felt like I had just done 12 rounds in the boxing ring with someone roughly 6.7 times my weight class. As for your experience, not only was this an incredibly cool opportunity (I as an Air Force Aviator only dream of getting a ride-along with the T-Birds), but you did really freaking well, man. Most people would've been tapping out on that departure alone. Be proud of what you got to do, and how much you withstood... It was WELL above average.

Also, thank you for this. I just showed my wife this because you put into a 30 min video a better explanation/representation of this kind of flying better than I could in hours/days of me trying to explain. Love your channel and keep up the great work!!!

A new adoption of the digital asset XRP could reach Asia. Ripple’s partner, SBI, has teamed up with crypto exchange FXCoin and others to develop an XRP based solution that reduces volatility when sending remittances. Announced in April of this year, the solution is expected to be launched in a test format by the end of November.

FXCoin is a relatively new exchange. Its operations began in 2018, founded by former Deutsche Bank employees. However, only at the end of 2019 it received a license from the Japanese regulator, the Financial Services Agency, to operate as an exchange.

The solution the exchange develops with SBI will allow users to send remittances without worrying about market fluctuations, changes in exchange rates or any of the other problems associated with sending remittances. The solution will be specially focused to be a tool that can be used by companies in Japan in need to send large amounts of money abroad. Senior strategist at FXCoin, Yasuo Matsuda said:

Until now, active crypto has been used mainly for speculative purposes due to the magnitude of price movements…

To establish the exchange market and expand the use for real demand, we will proceed with the demonstration experiment of domestic remittances and remittances abroad through the XRP, and finally, global cash management, corporate finance and trade.

Will the adoption of XRP increase?
The solution developed by FXCoin, SBI, and its partners responds to an internal demand for crypto-based products. According to the local Nikkei media report, many companies in Japan have stayed away from crypto payment solutions because of the risks associated with this asset class. Volatility is the main detractor.

Apparently, FXCoin has the support of a number of companies that have committed to using the solution, if the test phase is successful. That way, there could be an increase in the adoption of XRP and a positive impact on its performance in 2021.

As reported by CNF, FXCoin announced in late July the launch of an XRP based exchange to protect its users from sudden price fluctuations. At that time, it became known that SBI Holdings made an investment in the exchange.

SBI Holdings is one of Ripple’s biggest supporters in Asia. Yoshitaka Kitao, CEO of SBI Holdings, is considered a key player in the partnership between the financial institution and the payment solutions company. Kitao is part of Ripple’s board of directors. Recently, Ripple announced that it will make a new investment in MoneyTap, the money transfer application developed in conjunction with SBI Holdings.

I am late on this, and I am not sure if it has been posted. The F16 control stick actually was designed not to move, and only be based on pressure. During testing however, the pilots on testing did not like that it did not move, so a bit of movement was put in. That little bit of movement is combined with the pressure system for the Hands On Throttle And Stick (HOTAS). I am not sure why they decided on the no movement, but my guess is that with the cockpit being so small and compact, it made more sense, because the stick is right against the side of the cockpit.

A year ago last February, I had an infection in my vestibular system that destroyed my sense of balance.  My ears don't deliver the same "direction signals" to my brain, and of course my eyes contradict what my ears are trying to tell me (cue projectile vomiting, the room felt like it was spinning at 1000RPM).  This left me with pronounced nystagmus (like you were having in the chair) and constant vertigo.  They initially though I'd had a stroke (and i had to get the shots in the stomach, they didn't hurt much but left a belt of purple bruises around my waist) but stroke was completely ruled out and the diagnosis was a viral infection in my vestibular system (didn't hurt, oddly enough).  Long story short, I went through months of neuro physical therapy to get to where I could even go to the bathroom by myself (and not fall on the whole 15 foot trip), and after what is now closing on 2 years I can drive - carefully.  I still fall from time to time, especially when I turn too quickly to the right, but it's something I have to live with now.  So the vertigo you had there is "every day all day" for me.

In the movie "The Wright Stuff", Gordon Cooper aka "Gordo" was asked "Who's the best fighter pilot he ever saw"? Now obviously "Gordo" already had an sarcastic answer to the reporters question because it was his staple to say "Well your looking at him" but this time Cooper actually thought back and remembered another Air Force test pilot who although he didn't become one of the Majestic Seven, he was a highly respected test pilot whom most considered the best they had ever seen. His name was Charles "Chuck" Yeager! The point of saying this is to remind yourself that whatever you believe you've mastered, there's always the anomaly(in this case the Thunderbird pilots) out there, unseen by the rest of the world but proving day in, day out that they are the best of the best! Awesome video... However, the one really significant thing I think you were missing on that F16 ride was actually flying the aircraft, actually being in control.  I have had similar experiences in the T38, A7, and F15.  Riding in the back seat is fine until the pilot does something unexpected. For instance, you’re looking out the left and pilot suddenly rolls the airplane right.. Tumbles my gyros every time.  However, when I have control of the aircraft that queasy feeling immediately goes away and I can make those high G turns, roll it, split-S, and other maneuvers without getting sick because I know what to expect.   And, flying those kind of high performance aircraft with the great operational latitude as far as airspeed, G’s, climb and decent rates, and awesome almost limitless power they are like flying my PA-28-235 with power steering, titanium wings, and super charging...  Besides, everything about that flight was brand new to you but after a period of time and a few more flights you’ll become acclimated to that sort of environment and you’re tolerance level will increase to the point you won’t even think about it...

Hey Destin, Mach is widely misunderstood.  It is commonly thought that air density or altitude effects Mach.  It is solely a function of temperature and only temperature.  The lower the temperature the lower the speed required for Mach.  The reason you think it's lower speed at higher altitude is only because the temperature was lower not because you were higher AGL or lower air density.    Regarding handling G force, Aerobatic pilots are Amazing what they can tolerate.  They build-up tolerance and lose it if they stop for a while.  Personally, I was right with you when you tapped out and I was not in the jet.  You would probably love to do a show on Felix or Aaron with Red Bull flying upside down in the BO-105 helicopter.  There is some interesting engineering that allows the BO to do what other helicopters can not.  Reaching out, Art - Sage Cheshire Aerospace

I haven't read through all the comments to see if anyone else has told you this, so I'll give you a little piece of info.  You commented on the altimeter doing a big swing as you went supersonic.  The reason you saw such a large swing was because you never put the altimeter in the correct position for normal flight.  By that, I mean you were flying around in "PNEU" pneumatic rather than "ELEC" electric selected.  PNEU is that backup mode that provides raw data rather than corrected data. There is an internal vibrator the altimeter uses to be sure it doesn't have any sticking points or lag during normal flight as well as maneuvers.  I'm sure you're also aware of all the corrections and limitations that need to be accounted due to the basic design of altimeters. That is one reason the altimeter wouldn't be as smooth as it should be during flight, but more importantly, it is not sharing data with the CADC or central air data computer.  The CADC will account for all atmospherics during flight as it needs to provide very accurate info to a number of systems within the F-16 (or any jet with a CADC).  In PNEU it will jump around and not be smooth whereas once you select ELEC (small switch on the bottom right of the altimeter), it will smooth right out and provide more stable and accurate data.  If you had been in ELEC, I don't think the altimeter would have jumped more than about 50'.  At least that is my experience in the F-16 as well as a number of other fighters I've flown.  Also because the flight control system is always correcting to 1G flight, you won't feel or see when "Mach Tuck" occurs like it does in aircraft without an active flight control system. I was going ot have to leave Mommy  for as long as a round trip took to come back to get me, a matter of hours.  I was scared to death and refused. This seems like a lame example but - I played a sit down video game of a combat flight simulator. I'd played hundreds of these before but this one was different. The video filled up my entire vision and required you to chase another plane through a downtown, high-rise office building environment. You had to do rolls, banks and even negative G push overs to keep the target in your sights.

Something about the buildings and ground rushing by so quickly and all those rolls and banks and everything and man my brain was scrambled. And this was a simulator that was stationary on the ground. In other words, I experienced ZERO changes in gravity but it still scrambled my brain. BIG TIME.

I literally couldn't walk afterwards and had to just sit there and focus on the carpet and let things come back to normal for a few minutes. Then when I stood up, I was wobbly and uncomfortable and for a few hours after, I felt "not right" but that's the only way I can describe it. Sooo amazing these bodies of ours.

Hey Destin, that random eye movement you experienced on the chair is called vestibular nystagmus. Nystagmus (involuntary jerking of the eyes) is what police look for in DUI enforcement. Certain chemicals, like depressants (alcohol), cause Nystagmus at high concentrations. It shows up in both vertical and horizontal directions at high BAC and is what police look for during the "eye" test portion of the standardized field sobriety tests!

Nystagmus can also be caused by medical conditions such as diabetes or TBI's.

I think, especially in flight, the felt maneuvering effects by the people aboard are either felt much more by the passengers or much less by the pilot. I am a student pilot, and one of the requirements is basic level maneuvers. If I am in the plane with an instructor who is demonstrating the maneuvers, I actually get sick pretty easily but have no issues if I am performing the maneuvers myself. Or if people are passengers in a standard transmission vehicle, they will feel the shifting more than the driver. I think this is because the individual in control of the vehicle has more readiness and bodily coordination with the vehicle. I wouldn't scoff at 7.2 Gs. I'd probably pass out before five or lose my lunch.

At first I did not understand how the G-suit worked, I mean do the laces get tightened up when you are experiencing Gs or what else, how does it work!? But then while watching this video 3rd time (yes i am a huge SmarterEveryDay fan) I realized that at 24:27 if you notice closely you'll see how the G-suits gets inflated like a balloon putting pressure on the legs forcing all the blood back up to the upper body.
If anyone else missed that then this comment is for them :)

This was the first time I had seen this and it was really fascinating! And it also left me thinking about how the suit must be connected to something like a pressure tank and a sensor so that whenever the pilot experiences Gs the G-suit is inflated and whenever the pilot stabilizes the jet, the G-suit is deflated. I do not have much knowledge about this so please if anyone does know do tell me I would love to know!
Thanks :)

That's interesting that you have noticed, and compared and contrasted with the attitudes of these very professional pilots. Jic you hasn't already heard, there are 5 hazardous pilot attitudes that are taught in flight training:
1. Anti- authority
2. Impulsivity
3. Invulnerability
4. Macho
5. Resignation
These hazardous attitudes have been learned the hard way, in countless accidents that have been caused by pilots with these mindsets.
Clearly, the USAF makes sure that they don't have a psychological liability in the cockpit (especially in a single seat fighter). That's good how that was illustrated in your video.

That effect of your eyes. I have a condition called Nystagmus. My eyes do this involuntarily. It sometimes cases me to have to stop and sit down to keep from falling over. This rarely happens though. When I saw your eyes going like they were I knew immediately the feeling you were experiencing without ever having been put through such a test. It's cool for you to experience it. I, however, have never NOT experienced it. Not sure if you'll see this comment but I hope it gives you a little insight.

True story: Going back to Oki from Saudi, Desert Shield/Storm, was sleeping on top of RISK Kits, about 6" from heater duct. Woke up drenched in sweat because,  I was 6" from heater duct. Jumped down to get a lot of water because I was very dehydrated. As I was walking, we must have hit some dead air, because I was barely on my tippy toes. We were pulling negative G. Thinking if I was still on top of kits, I would have been plastered against the ceiling. This was a KC-135A by the way. I think you did good. BTW, MACE will put you to sleep!!!! "nothing happened" when you broke mach 1 because of a HUGE amount of brilliant engineering. As we moved toward supersonic flight, we discovered that the aircraft of the day would shake, rumble, and become uncontrollable. This was the so-called "sound barrier". It was not a physical barrier, but an engineering barrier. The design of the fuselage, wing, control surfaces, had to be radically changed. It was NOT easy and NOT cheap, and pilots got KILLED in the testing. NOW it is a smooth as a baby's bottom, but do NOT underrate the huge effort and expense that made such an achievement possible.

The stick in an F-16 is force sensitive. Meaning they don't move they just measure how much force you put on them. They do move ~1/4 for full deflection but that's not really how the input is being measured. Its all about how much force is being put in. The thinking behind it is the pilot can go from full left roll to full right roll in an instant, just much faster movements.

Destin, the F-16 has a unique flight control system, that's why you've felt and shown in the video that with a "little" movement in the stick the aircraft moved in the desired axis. The sidestick was initially designed to not move at all, but after some feedback from pilots they add like a null zone so the pilots would have more "feel" on the movement. The fly by wire computer detects how much movement you want by mesuring the strengh you put in the stick. I've never flown the F-16 but I love this aircraft since I was a kid. I fly the Airbus 320/321 and it shares the same principals with the F-16, but we have a free sidestick. The computer senses how much rate you want in a given axis by how fast you move the stick, limiting that movement to a certain G depending on the flight phase and if you are in normal conditions.

All good, only i am not sure if the aircraft altimeter isn't taking a reading from a separate static pressure port. I am not sure about the F16 in particular, but i know that pitot tubes are only used to measure pressure differential (deltaP) i.e. airspeed. And for altimetry (purely analog or otherwise) there is a dedicated one or more static ports, that give altitude reading after a mechanical correction for pressure. In the case of modern airliners, there are usualy three static ports going to an air data computer that compares the readings constantly (in the case of a malfunction, port blockage etc.) also adding a correction for local pressure, temperature and hunidity. Anyhow i am not a physicist, nor i am familiar with the F16 fighter aircraft and its instruments and the explanation for the altimeter jump is 100% correct, because it is a pressure jump as the aircraft hardly lost or gained any significant altitude while breaking the sound barrier. Viper guy here, I haven’t seen the altimeter make that move going super sonic, however I did notice your altimeter was set to “Pneu” which means is taking raw pneumatic inputs from the tubes. So you might gets those “jumps”. You typically, won’t see that because the electric mode (elec) takes inputs from multiple probe/ins modes. Pilot’s typically switch over from “pneu” to “elec” after we get the INS aligned. Cheers.

Your eyes and ears don't match up which is what causes the vertigo (spinning sensation even when you're not moving) and nystagmus (Horizontal or vertical unintentional jerking or repetitive eye movement). Your eyes are telling your brain that you're not moving and upright, however your ears ARE telling your brain you're spinning. Your eyes actually try to adjust your vision to how your ears feel. Hence why you get the jerking eye movement, because they want to level out to the position your brain is FEELING from what your ears are telling it and compensate for it. This is why when you're on a merry go round or something similar, you don't naturally stare forward, rather your eyes fixate on one point and your head turns with the direction of velocity giving you moments of clear vision because you rotate your eyes and head to focus.

I can relate in this way. I did a fam flight in a glider - never been up in the air before - and I learned that my physiology and mental state does four things. The excitement kicks in, the realization that this is absolutely real and the adrenaline starts flowing, the feeling of dread washes over you, and then finally the anticipation just before you start rolling. I don't know what that combination of feeling is called, but there's nothing like that anywhere else.
The other neat thing about a kinfe edge maneuver is the pilot has to add a bit of down elevator to compensate for the lift vector of both the wings and the body in order to keep a straight line. If he didn't, it would turn into a gradual turn towards canopy. Since it's performed at a lower altitude, the pilot has to input more down elevator because as you mentioned it - higher density at that altitude.

I once had a pilot school as a client and I was given an opportunity to go up in one of their aircraft. I expected a simple flight as a passenger over the south coast of England for 10 minutes or so.
Instead, I found myself in control of the aircraft from the second we left the hard standing until the pilot took control due to heavy cross wind on landing. Not much different, I guess, from a pupil's first flying lesson but I can tell you my heart was pounding when we were at the end of the runway and the pilot says: "Take your foot off the brake and when your speed gets to Xmph pull back on the stick..."
I really think if it hadn't been for the cross wind he would have had me land it as well.
Not quite 7.2G in a fast jet but that was my wildly exciting flight experience.

The lesson for all of us is to let things roll.  Destin feels a sense of failure for tapping out after 7.2 G.  What he does not realize, and what none of us subjectively realize, is that the world's opinion of us is an integration of the totality of our performances, not just the most recent, and not just the one we have over-elevated for ourselves.  Completing all the maneuvers was his goal and he missed it, but no one noticed and no one cares.  What we care about is that Destin did another awesome thing and taught us the science of it.  It takes a lifetime to learn to "take it easy on yourself."

Thanks so much for sharing this, Destin. What an incredible opportunity. I'm an aeronautical engineer myself, and have studied this same stuff for years. What I wouldn't give to experience it all in person!
In fact, that why I got my glider license. Its been a chance to experience some of these aeronautical concepts first hand. 4 G maneuvers, inverted flight, spins, stalls, etc. (glider aerobatics are a fascinating application of energy conservation), but It only scratches the surface. I doubt I'll be going supersonic in a glider anytime soon. I love flight science and for me, getting to fly is a way to understand it from the inside out. I often tell other pilots, I want to understand flight from both sides of the drawing board. I sincerely hope one of these days I'm able to have an opportunity myself to ride second seat in jet fighter. We'll see!
Thanks again!

Mach is actually a function of temperature, not altitude.
The calibrated airspeed is lower due to the lower density of the air, but at the lower temperature Mach 1 is also a little lower in terms of true airspeed (TAS) , but nowhere near the degree you saw in the CAS.
Given the same temperature at two altitudes, Mach 1 would be at the same TAS

Dude, I flew in the vomit comet (parabolic arcs in a jet). The secret is: a double dose of Dramamine -- damps your sensitivity to the hair cells in your vestibular system -- lots of people barfed, I felt mostly fine. Oh, and don't look side to side much -- one more coordinate change your brain doesn't have to deal with. Straight ahead as much as you can. Of course, experienced pilots become acclimated to the Gs and don't need all this, but entering as a newbie, it ups your odds of not feeling weird or nauseous.

@21:44 - When his eyes were bouncing back and forth, that was the same thing your eyes do when you are drunk and trying to follow a moving object (but caused in a different way). It’s called post-rotational nystagmus. The road side sobriety test cops use is testing for a different thing, which has the same effects. When you’re intoxicated by alcohol and some other drugs, your nervous system experiences the same effects that Destin felt when he was spinning around.

By the way, there is some math to determine the angle of bank based on the number of G's being pulled in level turn which at 200 feet you better by flying level.  Basically it is the arc tan of square root of (G's squared minus 1 squared)  So if she is pulling 9G's it is Arc Tan of (square root (81 - 1)), Square root of 80 is about  8.944 and Arc Tan (8.944) is 83.6 degrees, so she hits about 83 degrees of bank if she is flying level and pulling 9Gs.

If anyone can help me with this, I will give an exclusive interview.
I am proud to have helped the General Dynamics/Lockheed Martin F-16 become one of the worlds best multirole fighters, especially in the dogfight arena. In 1979 there were three unexplained CFIT (Controlled Flight Into Terrain) crashes and the entire fleet was grounded. I knew the problem and independently came up with a solution. After many months to locate just the person to discuss the solution, I spoke with Lt Col Kramer at Wright Patterson AFB for about an hour to provide information for the PGCAS - Preventative Ground Collision Avoidance System. At the time, 25 of our nation's best were sequestered working on the solution, and Lt Col Kramer was very appreciative of my input. Since F-18 pilots brag they can exceed human limits using the system, and confirming the project is declassified, though I never will or have discussed the technology, I now can speak of my involvement in the success of the F-16 Falcon!! I have tried to find someone to authorize that I can go for a ride. If anyone knows where and how this can be accomplished, please let me know. I have delayed considering to have a ride due to injuries from a car crash, but have recovered well enough to enjoy the flight!! So, if anyone can have someone contact me so I can have a ride in the magnificent F-16, please have them contact me. I have talked with Col Lawhead at the pentagon and verified my involvement. Col Lawhead was surprised I had such information on a black project (I have the information because I lived it), but could not help me to schedule a ride. I contacted President Trump also, with no success. After 40 years, I think I have earned the privilege of a ride. I was in discussion to make arrangements for a ride some 35 years ago, but a crash of an F-7 with a civilian passenger caused a mandate to not have civilians as passengers for decades. That mandate has been rescinded. I hope to have my dream fulfilled before I die. In my mid 60's now, the timeclock is ticking.

I was in the 159thCAM and got my chance to do a DACT (Dissimilar Aircraft Combat Training) I.E> go up in the back seat of an F15 against a simulated enemy aircraft over the Gulf of Mexico. We were doing some incredible maneuvers (dog fight) as the scheduled F4 had issues and they sent up an F15A model instead. We pulled -3.2g, +10.3g, and Mach 1.3 during the manuvers. I even got to turn the aircraft around and head to the start zone after each maneuver... best 3-hours ever. I would do it again if I had the chance. I only wish i had a GoPro back then. (1993 or so.)

Destin, I have come to understand the complexities and similar personality traits of high achieving or very devoted people. Over the years I have been privileged to meet scores of Special Forces Operators representing all branches of our military and a few from other countries. These men all tend to have a very high degree of modesty and they are surprisingly grounded in humility. This is not at all the what most people would expect.
These people, like the men and woman you experienced have a tremendous degree of responsibility, knowledge and expertise in their chosen field, and yet they’re blessed with the gift of modesty. They don’t come across as loud boasters or egomaniacal divas. And I believe that at the core of this trait lies their observation of those who came before them. Not humility via tradition alone but an actual transformation in the DNA of their perceived self. Of course there will always be a bad nut in the batch but those people tend to get weeded out by attrition or fail in the early stages of training by the group. This is not an absolute guarantee however.
Another reason may be their understanding of the distinct position they hold. They appreciate their unique position in that their are only small numbers of people that pass through training and are employed in their field. This brings about a bond among them which is where humility is an established trait among their peers. Esprit de Corps.

The eye movement seen in the seated chair spin, is a perfect demonstration of what we look for when we do Field Sobriety Tests...specifically the HGN test  or Horizobtal Gaze Nastagmus Test. Alcohol is a depressant, which means it depresses your brain or bodies ability to stop Nastagmus. The ye muscles cease to work, which means we can physically see you are drunk.

So Dustin; just in case your wondering...when you went super sonic and it didn't go as you expected it to with the vibration or lack there of; that's because the Viper has a flight computer that makes micro adjustments  100's of times per second. So basically it's changing the position of your control surfaces for the different flight profiles/speeds your in. All modern fighter air craft are inherently unstable air craft. If it wasn't for the computer; you would be fighting it every step of the way until landing. But good video either way. I may not be able to do the high level math but I understand the concepts of everything you talked about and what Mace talked about. When your going through pilot training for fighter's regardless of branch each pilot candidate has to go through the centrifuge doing 10G for 30 seconds. Not allowed to black out aka GLOC while holding a flight stick and chasing a "virtual bandit" to make sure they can sustain more G then the aircraft will allow. They also wear the G-suit but it's not hooked up at all.

Destin, the maneuver that got you was essentially the same one that caused the terrible accident with TB4 Cajun DelBagno a few years back.   The Accident Investigation Board determined that while inverted, he was experiencing about 1.5 Gs negative, and then with an aggressive Split-S, not unlike the one you experienced, he went close to 9 Gs positive.   He was a VERY experienced fighter pilot and he G-LOC'd....and unfortunately, he was all alone in the jet.  So don't feel bad about what happened.  That kind of a G-swing really throws the human body for a loop.

My time in the military left me with a paralyzed Vestibular nerve on the right side. My otoliths don't communicate to my brain. So, I get random bouts of vertigo. I'm quite familiar with the inner workings of the inner ear as a result. I never got to see my own eyes spas out like that, so it was really cool to see it on here!
As for forced humbleness, you should try 10th Planet Jiu-Jitsu in Decatur, AL
There are few things in life, that have humbled me as much as jiu-jitsu has. There are tiny women there that will literally feel like a brick wall has landed on you. They will mangle you, and no matter how much you try, you will NOT be able to escape getting tapped out.
It will humble you, and it's really quite an amazing experience. You encounter a gym full of Mace's. Very humble people because they too have been force fed humility. And talk about super human powers! Jiu-Jitsu will blow your mind.
It's just down the road from you, Destin. You should totally check it out. I would love to see a video on that! Trust me, there is a TON of science at play there, too!

The video emphasizes that the pilots train to be able to handle these G's, and we see the difference in how well they tolerate them vs. Destin, but how? What are they physically doing that he didn't? He did the clenching and used the G-suit just like them. What more can a human do to control their blood flow? Surely they're not doing training that lets them control where their blood flows; humans have no power over that. The hair cells in their ears are experiencing the same effects Destin's did, and that's the core of the human orientation system and we don't get to control that. How can training possibly give them influence over these autonomous bodily functions? It's like saying that you can train your tongue to not taste something that's placed on it. The tongue just naturally tastes by default and we don't have any control over it. What would that training possibly be?

I'd like to add one detail to this that may have been cut from the final video. The role of the Thunderbirds is truly multifaceted. First and foremost is the role of ambassadors who represent the USAF Core Values and capabilities that support and defend the US Constitution of the USA. They may also remind us of the incredible efforts and sacrifices made by the people of the US Armed Services who are engaged in combat or peacetime missions around the world.

The capabilities of the F-16 and the expert pilots showcased in this video are just a glimpse into the world of combat pilots and their support teams who use maneuvers like these demonstrated to engage or evade malicious forces. To learn more about those types of maneuvers consider checking out Strategic Air Combat Maneuvers (SACM).

I'm sure Maj. Jason Markzon, Maj. Michelle Curran and the rest of the Thunderbird team would agree their wingmen in the line of fire are where our hearts and minds should be. I appreciate the Thunderbird team's willingness to step away from their combat mission to inspire us with a glimpse into the "shock and awe" they rain down on the enemies of the USA and our allies.

P.S. This is really cool. Thanks again for sharing your journey in the F-16.

P.P.S. Legs tight! Butt tight! Breath!

I drew a lot of parallels between what you said about balancing humility and confidence with my own motorcycle operator training. I definitely don't want to minimize what these pilots do; these two skills are in an entirely different league and for very good reason. But a huge part of that riding training is tempering beginner overconfidence with the necessary humility to perform an activity at the dangerous end of the everyday spectrum with safety and responsibility. All while also building up the basic skills to have warranted confidence in your own ability.

Again, the margins aren't at all similar; these pilots surpasses the ordinary and really climb figuratively and metaphorically into the extraordinary. But for an ordinary person like me, operating a motorcycle definitely presents some of the narrowest safety margins I can experience, and thus requires the same kind of balance between those two aspects of myself as these pilots.

Many kudos on making it as far as you did with those maneuvers. That's not the kind of thing that most people could tolerate and handle as well as you did. Additionally good luck in finding the right balance in your future endeavors!

I have a weird point to make.  I feel like I would have no problem pulling 7 G's If I WAS IN CONTROL.  It's like a roller coaster, or just flying in a plane for me... I have no control.  Which makes me freak out.  I have a hard time doing roller coaster, or even flying a plane.  I do them, and after a couple of times in close proximity it doesn't bother me at all.  But this has me questioning whether it's control, or a built up tolerance.  For instance If I'm in someone else's car and they mash the gas it makes me feel uneasy.   But if I make that choice I knew what was coming and I can stop when I feel uncomfortable. I know Destin couldn't do this test with him flying it.  But I would love to see Destin put himself in an uncomfortable situation where he is at the wheel for instance.  I feel like you can push yourself much farther rather than just praying for it to end.

My dad was a mechanic in the Air Force, so naturally, he'd take me to air shows all the time. I was fascinated, especially by the Thunderbirds, so you could imagine that my childhood dream was to be a fighter pilot. Unfortunately, as I grew up, my dreams became a "self-relatively" unrealistic. I kept telling myself my eyesight wasn't great, I kept telling myself I wasn't physically strong enough, and I kept telling myself I wasn't smart enough to get a Bachelor's Degree to become an officer. After enlisting in 2011, I've since met many pilots who wore glasses, also thought college wasn't possible, and weren't necessarily body-builders, but the difference between them and myself is that they had a confidence and attitude I didn't have. Don't sell yourselves short.

Patient Medical Journal, a publication from the Finnish Medical Association, carried an article on February 7 with a title of “Where Do the Organs for Transplants in China Come From?” It discussed the concerns raised in medical publications over the organ transplantation ethics in China.


Patient Medical Journal, a publication from the Finnish Medical Association, published an article on February 7, 2018, discussing forced organ harvesting in China.

“China did not have a national organ donation system until the end of 2013. In 2011, only 37 people in China were registered as donors. The national donation system has not succeeded in acquiring significant quantities of transferring organs since, according to traditional Chinese practices, the deceased are left untouched after death,” said the article.

This raised many questions since a large number of transplants take place in China every year. Because of that, China admitted using executed prisoners as a source of organs. The number of prisoners executed is only a fraction of total transplants carried out in China, however.

Now think about this, World War 2 pilots did not have these G suits. They relied completely on their own muscular power. Planes like the spitfire and zero that were known for turning. Their pilots were subjected to extremely high G forces with no form of assistance. While jets offer a different way for their pilots to experience Gs. A prolonged sog fight with constant maneuvering and hard pulls constantly forcing a pilot to squeeze his blood back to the brain. I respect these pilots for pushing human capability to the edge. But there is a different kind of respect and admiration I have for the post of world war 2, they where pulling high Gs when diving on each other and the entire time they are managing their plane as they have no fancy computer systems to do it for them. These pilots used the best technology the world's militaries had and fought each other without the assistance of a G suit, or jet engines, or fly by wire avionics

For anyone wondering, the F-16's joystick doesn't move much at all when using it because it is a pressure sensitive joystick. The reason sidestick in f-16 bearly moves is that in early versions it was pressure based and later made with minimal movement. To turn at a maximum rate you need to move it a little bit (dont know how much but probably around 1-2cm). Its made this way to minimize effects of hight G load. You cant move it like in any other planes. (might be wrong somewhere since I'm not a f-16 pilot :) )

Here is a portion of the email regarding the hydration:
"Now, some things to keep in mind to make your flight as enjoyable as possible:
There are a few things you can do to minimize the possibility of you being airsick during your flight – Hydrate, sleep and eat. Starting right NOW -- hydrate. Drink more water than you normally do… then drink some more. Hydration combats motion sickness, so this step is key. Please do this only until the evening to avoid the need to use the restroom every few hours during the night, as sleep is important as well. Try to get a good night's rest -- at least 7 hours if possible. The day of your flight, we want you to have food in your stomach, but nothing greasy and nothing spicy. I'd recommend fruit, bread, bagels, oatmeal, light sandwiches, or (my personal favorite) peanut butter and banana toast. Please also bring some kind of light snack in case your flight is delayed. The day of the flight, minimize caffeine and carbonation. Both are diuretics and will counteract your hydration efforts."

Right around 22:05 I started crying a little. A couple of years ago I had a common cold, nothing fancy, but somehow it hit one of my ears as well. I have a history of ear problems from my youth so I'm accustomed to have one ear be closed off for a couple of hours, no big deal. But this time it was different, according to the ENT-specialist in the hospital I had caught a virus which caused the proteins in the fluid to bunch together creating 'flakes' if you will, actually exactly as the ones in the bottle she holds up. So every move I make is amplified by those flakes, all day every day. It's often referred to as benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The way the lady in your video explained it was SPOT ON and the best explanation I have ever seen. Sadly it can't be fixed through a medical procedure but I can subdue the effect through medication, bottom line is I will never be able to perform any activities anymore which require me to tumble around or be upside down or anything. Something I never would have had any trouble with at any point in my life. 'You feel miserable' she says. Yes lady, you are very very correct.

So Youtube suggested Gerard Butler apparently getting 9.4G same team 4 years prior. I am not trying to make any comparisons between Destin or Gerard, certainly having myself no experience of pulling more Gs than rollercoasters can deliver, but it does show that what Destin's saying about the inner ear as well as any cardiovascular strength a former Spartan may have to help pump your arteries to keep blood flowing at 9G helps. Those pilots though, and you can even compare their jumpsuit fit to Gerard Butler's, they're bulging out of their suits and are in regular exposure to the strains this puts on their bodies and if they break from flight time the extreme resilience dulls. They are consciously flexing muscle groupings to help their vascular pressure which becomes insufficient to move the liquid blood under maneuvers approaching 10G. Even their diaphragm and intercostal muscles (breathing anatomy that operates the lungs like bellows) will be incredibly developed from their regimen of physical duress in their job.

At 24:24 you said "look how little the stick moves to pull a high G maneuver", but the F-16 stick is unlike any other, as it does not gimbal.


Instead, it's actually almost fixed in place, and sensors inside the base measure TINY deflections to calculate how much the stick is being pushed. So you're quite literally bending very strong metal and the computers is seeing that.

I love your videos but that was the best!  I was a flight surgeon flying the Strike Eagle out of Seymour Johnson AFB in the late 90’s.  I got just under 100 flights in 2 years.  I never got close to the level of awareness that the real flyers maintained during their flights.  We would debrief after and the pilot could recreate the entire engagement on a whiteboard with headings speed, altitude and tactical situation all from memory (and there would be several engagements for each flight) and for me it was all a blur,  those guys(and gals...we had the first operational female fighter pilot in my squadron) really are superhuman.  I think you captured the experience very well.  Thank you! (Don’t sweat the 9 g’s. I did it twice in the centrifuge, after 7.5 it’s all about survival.  It doesn’t feel any different)

24:25 The reason why the control stick barely moves is because the F16 has a force-sensing stick, rather than the conventional deflection-sensing stick that moves around. It relies on sensors that detect the pressures exerted on the stick by the pilot, while the stick remains fairly static (it used to be completely static, but they added about 1/4" movement as seen in the video, to help pilots differentiate roll vs pitch inputs, and also because pilots were adding too much input to the point the planes would return to the hangar with bent sticks!). This apparently allows for less delay for reactionary inputs through the FBW system, and actually gave pilots better control and tactility of their flight inputs, especially under high G maneouvres.

I had the opportunity, as a glider rated pilot, to fly a non-hydraulic, F16 simulator, that my pilot, bro-in-law used to train other F-16 pilots. With a little power management help, I rotated and was airborne. The fly-by-stick is interesting to use and requires very little movement, unlike the stick in a 1-26 sailplane. Other than that, it handled well and I was even able to enter the pattern and land without any trouble. Aside from the lack of physics on my body, it was an awesome experience that I will never forget.

While following a bug in the HUD, I did unexpectedly crashed while pulling back from a roll while following the target. My B-I-L was laughing after I questioned why the crash. Seems, I still had the afterburners on and drove into the ground at 450 knots.

Actually, on the knife edge the rudder lift is down towards the ground, the opposite of the vertical stabilizer. So Vertical stabilizer lift is up, while the rudder lift is down. Maximum body lift is achieved when the rudder hits the hard stop with rudder lift down.

Better wording for the decrease in altitude would be,  "The Pressure at the Static Port went up as the Bow ShockWave moves forward across the static ports on it's way to the tip of the Pitot Tube."   The Bow ShockWave does not form at the nose of the aircraft at Mach 1. What it does is move forward from some wider part of the aircraft were the Bow Shock formed prior to Mach 1.  The Tail of the Aircraft always achieves Supersonic Flight before the Nose. The Sound Barrier actually sneaks up from behind, as the Wake ShockWave always form first grows larger and larger as velocity increase. At Mach 1 the Wake Shockwave grows from finite to infinite, the discontinuity in the equations.

Minor correction... the human body isn't the limiting factor in an F-16's turn rate. The airframe is only rated to take 9G, and the fly-by-wire artificially limits the controls to prevent exceeding that. Some humans (and some planes) are able to go higher, at least for a short time... I'd be fairly confident guessing these pilots are among them.

The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade and Defence of the Irish Parliament discussed the issue of forced organ harvesting in China on July 6, 2017. The committee recommended that the legislature do what it can to stop this brutality and urged the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to bring this up at the Council of Foreign Ministers with the European Union.

Renowned human rights lawyer David Matas and investigative writer Ethan Gutmann attended the meeting and were joined by Irish transplant surgeon Conall O'Seaghdha and James McDaid.


Hearing on Forced Organ Harvesting in China by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Defence in the Irish Parliament on July 6, 2017.

Actions Against Heinous Crimes

Committee Chair Brendan Smith said the committee will ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to raise the issue with the European Union.

Committee Chair Brendan Smith reiterated in the European Convention against Trafficking in Human Organs, adopted in 2015, “The Irish Department of Health must introduce legislation to transpose those provisions into domestic law. All member states can transpose the provisions of that convention into domestic legislation. That is the value of the European convention.”

More specifically, he said that the committee will “communicate directly with the Minister for Health following this meeting, stating that we had a formal meeting with the witnesses in regard to the need to bring forward this legislation.” He is sure this would meet with the approval of both Houses of the Oireachtas.

BTW, back in the day there was a  Wright Lab program called the AFTI/F-16 that had as one part what was  called the high acceleration cockpit (HAC) that looked at  further reclining the F-16 seat from 30 degrees to 60 degrees  for high G maneuvers. It was like  Mounting a lazy Boy recliner into the ejection seat only the back did not reclione but rather the seat itself raised up. I am not sure that ever got tested in the AFTI/F-16 program or not. The idea was that maybe with the HAC pilots withstand even higher G's than 9 G''s. But the airframe was only rated at 9Gs so it would have been quite costly to incorporate even if it did work and allowed the human to withstand higher G's.  As such it was just a experiment that probably will fade into history to never be ever  implemented in the field but as such might be worth mentioning here.

Destin... I am a Navigator in the Air Force and loved your explanation of the calibrated airspeed and altitude changes with the pitot tube. As an engineer I'm sure you are aware of the heat of compression in the pitot tube as well which changes pressure. Most modern aircraft have a computer that compensate for this. But aircraft actually have 4 different airspeeds Indicated, Calibrated, Equivalent, and True. When trying to figure out what our speeds are we use a calculation we affectionately call the ICE-T or reverse ICE-T. It would be a a cool idea to have a video explaining these and their differences in only the way your channel does. Just a thought in case you run out of other awesome ideas. Thanks for your videos!

Brain uses multiple inputs beyond just the semicircular canals. Visual cues are probably the 2nd most important. But also nerve ending inputs from the hairs on your face, arms, lets, etc, all get incorporated. It will also use the feedback from muscular nerves on what they are having to do to maintain body position. Most of the time, all of these inputs agree with each other. That's why the chair was so confusing... your inner ear was telling your brain one thing (the primary input) but all the other inputs were saying something different. High gs does that too as it puts an external force on your muscular system, reported by the nerves back to the brain as being in a certain direction, but your eyes are saying you aren't moving relative to the plane, yet your inner ear is saying you are definitely moving. It's conflicting signals.
Which is why Mace can be so humble about 9g... it is an acquired skill. Not everyone can do it, but you can train your brain, through repetition, to disregard conflicting inputs, or minimize them. Like learning a language, or a chef who can rapid chop food without worrying about cutting their fingers off... they have created, through repetition and practice, connections in their brain that handle the inputs and expected outputs. So now her brain knows to disregard the signal from her inner ear and rely more heavily on visual and other inputs when she is in the jet. Her brain will even begin to use the inputs from the aircraft systems themselves.
They did an experiment once in which they had people wear a belt that had rumble packs all around it, and the one that was facing north would vibrate. They wore them for a few weeks. In that time, most of the people's brains integrated the sensory input as a new "sense." An innate sense of direction. The brain is really good at matching up data and so would take visual cues and pair them up with this new information. After the few weeks they took the belts off to see what would happen. Most of the people reported continuing to have a very intuitive sense of direction. A few reported even still being able to feel the vibration in the proper place as they turned. IE the brain was supplying to inferred feedback from the rumble pack as a phantom sensory input to match the other sensory data it did have. The brain is unbelievably good at this sort of thing. It's how you can drive home from work and when you pull in you stop and try to remember stopping at red lights... but you can't. You know you must have, but you can't remember it. Your brain just handled it for you in the background without interrupting you. It saw nothing out of the ordinary so the built up pathways just did their thing. You slowed the car, stopped, watched for the green, all while your conscious thought processes were free to think about other things, or sing Taylor Swift at full volume. This is sometimes called rote learning.
Sorry for the novel, but this ability of the brain fascinates me, and it applies to everything we do as humans. It's one of the keys to our rise to the top of the food/evolution pyramid on Earth. Anyway, I'm super jealous of your chance to fly with the Falcons. I, like you, would love to think I got this. I've flown 10s of thousands of hours in flight simulators since I was 6 years old. I've played fighter games, etc. I majored in astrophysics so the math makes perfect sense. I know how planes work, etc. But I also know that knowing, and feeling directly are not the same thing. So the "coriolis effect" she talks about at 23 minutes in, I've experienced. I fell hard onto my left ear when wake boarding and punctured my ear drum, and subsequently damaged my inner ear from water being forced into my ear. Seconds after it happened I had absolutely ZERO sense of direction. I felt like I was spinning, tumbling, accelerating and decelerating all at the same time. Even though only one ear was damaged it was disorienting enough that I couldn't keep myself above water. Even with a vest on I was essentially drowning. Luckily a friend got me out of the water but it took a solid week for me to feel somewhat normal again. I still have bouts of vertigo that are supposedly linked to my inner ear damage. All that to say, when she says "it's miserable." Believe it.

I just finished my aerodynamics class and i just want to clarify wether i misunderstood something or wether the models we talked about were simplified.
You said that air in front of a shockwave is at high pressure and after the shockwave there is lower pressure.
The way i learned it, pressure jumps up on shockwave boundaries. In front of the first shockwave is free stream static pressure and it jumps when moving through the wave.
Then the static pressure mostly remains the same until the next shockwave (or prandtl-meyer-expansion fan). What i though was going on is that the static pressure holes are behind 1 shockwave (generated by the cone's deflection of the air) and 1 expansion fan (created by the transition into a cylinder after the cone in front).
During a transition through a shockwave, total pressure is lost, and therefore, after you "re-expand" the flow back to parallel to the free stream, your static (and dynamic) pressure will be lower than free stream values.
The drop in pressure right when going through the sound barrier i though had something to do with relatively huge losses in total pressure due to bow shock. This occurs because supersonic streams have a maximum deflection angle for oblique shockwaves (the ones you showed in the Schlieren image). If you exceed this angle (and that angle increases with Mach number, M1.1 gives you about 1,8° theoretical max deflection while M2 can reach 23°), bow shock will occur. This isnt an oblique shockwave and will sharply increase air restistance and total pressure loss. Once you move through that, oblique shockwaves will form and reduce restistance and pressure loss.

Even from the safe distance behind a screen, this is humbling. I'm thankful for your honest approach, and I realized how my confidence shows more often at inappropriate times than I would like to admit. Even if I know I'm right about something, the line between confidence and arrogance is very thin. I'm the type of person that prefers to be right, even if I'm going to be disliked for it.
But thanks to you showing how it looks like to be humbled by external force, it got me thinking. What good is it to be right, when your knowledge doesn't serve anybody, because nobody would like to take your advice?

Another thing I learned is, how intriguingly interesting this topic of combat flight is from a technical point of view. As a German pacifist I'm fairly critical towards anything related to military, even though I'm aware of it's necessity. Our history taught me to be wary of military force in nationalist (it even just patriotic) context, and it keeps me to oppose most military action I come across regarding German politics. I know and accept it's culturally a different topic in the USA.
But even as a pacifist I'm increasingly fascinated by military technology (minus the weapons), and how it pushes the limits of the human body. So thank you for making me appreciate the incredible work of the people you introduced today, regardless of my personal views.

God bless you, and keep you and your loved ones healthy and safe.
