Maybe I just missed it, but I don't recall you explaining why you can fly faster at higher altitude.
So it's a combinations of 2 factors:
1. Speed of sound in a given medium is a function of density. As that lowers, so does the speed of sound. Remember, the Mach number is your speed relative to the speed of sound.
2. With less density, the drag also decreases. There's "less" air molecules that have to be pushed to the side in a given time. With less drag, more of the engines thrust can directly be converted to speed.

So what do we have? We have higher speed due to less drag. We also have a lower velocity to go faster than.
Those combined tells WHY it's easier to go supersonic at higher altitude.

Hi Destin,
That was a great opportunity indeed! And a great video as always.
Only, as an aeronautical engineer, I think you made a small mistake in the explanation of the pitot tube.
The hole up front measures the Total pressure by ‘stagnating’ the air so the dynamic pressure is zero and only the static pressure remains, which is measurable.
The total pressure will not change with the airspeed. At least not with the assumptions of Bernoulli’s equation you used to calculate the airspeed. (So yes flying supersonic is messing it up)
The static pressure however will decrease with the airspeed since the dynamic pressure increases.
This mistake is often made because this explanation just makes more sense to us.
Sorry for beating your confidence even more, but at least you became smarter today 😉.

Altitude has nothing to do with mach speed, only temperature has a effect on mach speed. Which is the reason that mach speed gets lower at higher altitude is due to temperature drop with height and not the pressure. So 1 mach at the poles at a 1000 feet would not be same as in the middle east.
The reaseon why the stick doesn't move much is due to high g maneuver, imagine trying to move the stick when you have 9g. Original the stick didn't move at all, but the pilot complained that they didn't have any feel of the aircraft, so manifactor made som slack into it to give some feel to the pilot.

Quite a few years ago I had the opportunity to experience some heavy G's in the back seat of a T-28 Trojan. Was told how to counter the G's and how to breathe when doing it (didn't have a G suit). We did some mild aerobatics pulling more and more G's until I was asked if I wanted to join the 10 G club. What was I going to say, No? We rolled into a turn and slowly brought the G's up until we got to 5-6 and then much quicker up to just over 10, held that for about one second, then quickly back down and rolled level.
For me 1-3 G's was like a roller coaster, you could feel it but it was fun.
4-6 G's started to get more and more uncomfortable.
7+ G's was no longer fun.
10 G's was literally painful. I did it, don't need to do it again.

I have also spoken with several F-16 pilots. I asked one of them about the control stick / flying the aircraft. He told me that if you think about moving the stick you're going to over control the aircraft. He said you lightly grip the stick, don't think about moving it, just think about what you want the aircraft to do and it does it. Almost like it can read your mind.

Destin if you see this comment, I wanted to leave you with a tidbit of information. The flight path marker that was being discussed in the latter part of your video is a complex mathematical calculation made by the aircraft computer. If you were to do a follow up on the topic of flight, you might find how the airplane uses the various instrumentation to make that calculation. Everything from the position of the flight controls, the pilot input, to the calculated weight of the aircraft based on fuel load is all accounted for. The pilot is simply responding to that mathematical calculation to prevent the aircraft from crashing. In the science of how humans interface with things, it's called human factor engineering. All kinds of things are decided using this science discipline.

Just think of the poor Blue Angels as unlike the Thunderbirds they don't wear a G suit.
This is due to the difference between the FA-18 and F-16 cockpits.
The FA-18's control column is between the pilots knees and their hand rest on their knee, this would cause unintended control inputs as the G suit inflated.
The F-16's control stick is off to the side and the pilots arm rests on a arm rest which permits them to use a G suit.

I stopped arguing with people on the internet as a past-time because of the handful of times I was humbled by force. As in, having what I thought I knew thrown in my face as blatantly wrong. I was often right, but I realized just being right doesn't help anyone. It pisses them off because they can often immediately tell that you're trying to explain that you're right, not trying to understand their perspective. Now I see it everywhere I look, like when you buy a car and suddenly realize how many people drive the same type of car. This psychology seems to exist in many people, from simple internet arguments to the opinions of doctors and professionals, and to a common guy getting in a fighter plane. "I know what's going on, you be quiet and let me tell you".
Socrates said it best, "know that you don't know".

I'm a pilot in training and I can tell you that at the beginning of this video, all that prep work is key. If you don't have a good nights sleep and hydrate, you are toast. It can actually make the difference between you feeling ok and wanted to tap out. Could actually be why 7.2 ended up making Destin tap out. That extra bit of sleep could have done it right there.  Your flight actually starts the day before, eating properly and getting good solid sleep. You may think you'll be fine if you didn't sleep a solid 7+ hours straight, you'll wake up fine, excited, feeling normal... When it comes time to be in the cockpit doing maneuvers and becoming task saturated, you'll be wishing you got extra hours of sleep. Hydration is another one, you will feel the difference if you do not follow these rules, people always think it's not that big of a deal, but you'll think it is by the end of your flight lol. Now this was a ride-along flight for Destin, which is different than learning to fly and going through multiple procedures, just imagine what it's like when you have tons of training to accomplish, remembering training, learning new tasks, etc... Flying isn't easy even at 1.5G. I'm glad to see someone talk about the inner ear issues as well, a simple head turn during a maneuver can ruin your day. Happened to me on one of my first flight lessons, my flight instructor had taken over the controls to start landing and in that single moment my inner ear went nuts. One little head bump or turn really takes a number on you, and it takes training to get over it. Keep up the great videos, always watch your new ones!

I'm positive at my age..53 I could not endure even what you did.. my body is shot now..
However, when I was 10 ish there was one thing I wanted to do.. Be a fighter pilot.. I read books about it I talked to pilots at College Park airport.. (look that up.. I grew up 3 miles from it..)
I watched planes fly over, I made paper planes and "piloted" them with radio calls, taxied them on dirt runways, blew up targets with dropped rocks.. and understood lift and glide angles and G's, and shear, jet wash etc.. waiting for the time I could get into a military program or pilot school even before that...
Then I turned 12 ish... And I was having a hard time seeing the chalkboard in school.. And it got worse fast..
By 13 I was in glasses full time and changed prescriptions twice in one year.. (by the time I had Lasik done 20 years ago I was -7.5 in one and-8 in the other.. "blind" without glasses..)
At 14 ish I actually had my optometrist say.. "Well, hope you didn't ever want to be a fighter pilot, your eyes are past correctable for that now.." He didn't even know what he just did to me...
The only thing I ever REALLY wanted to do... And never will.

See if you can get a centrifuge ride. All F16 F22 F15 F35 guys do this to see if they have the physical stamina for 9g. If not, you'll tap out as single pilot, and are essentially useless to employ the jet. There you can play with g loads and learn to build tolerance your way and see what your body does after a period of time. G tolerance is learned, your body adapts to it. If you stop flying for a week or so you'll feel a little weird until your body readjusts. Anyway, just a suggestion.

11 years ago I got to fly with the Thunderbirds too! We didn't go supersonic, something about scaring the people and breaking windows over CONUS. We maxed out at .98 mach but we did pull 9.2g and I got the pin to prove it. 9.2g is physically painful. I had my hands on my thighs and couldn't lift them. You are right, it is the opportunity of a lifetime, I would do it again in a heartbeat.


When you woke up the next day were you sore? I could barely walk I hurt so bad. I got to see my pilot 2 days later and he said "I didn't do very well if you could get out of bed the next day". It wore me out and I was used to being worn out working on the fire dept. And the drive home, going 80 was like standing still. I couldn't drive, I would have been going 150.


Sitting in the back seat as we passed over the end of the runway I had to lean forward a bit to see my family on the ground passing at 400 miles an hour. When we pulled up the g put my head between my knees and there was nothing I could do to move it until the g let off going vertical.


The g practice we pulled 7 and I was ok. First your vision goes blurry like looking through a fish bowl. Pulling 9g was an entirely different experience. Everything got fuzzy, then I lost the colors, everything was black and white. I remember my pilot calling out 8 and then the edges started closing in on me. Blackness started at the edges and rapidly moved toward the middle. Just before the g let off it was like looking through a paper towel roll, at a fishbowl, in black and white. I was probably within a couple of seconds of gLOC.


It was amazing and I am happy you got to do it as well.


Full disclosure, I did puke. Twice. Once after the 9g pull and once under negative g. We had done an aileron roll vertically from 12,000 up to 40,000 feet and the pilot wanted to get back down low into the thick air to do some maneuvers and he pointed the nose down and goosed the throttle and we dropped fast back to 12,000. Negative g puts your stomach in your throat and we had held it for a minute or longer. That made me lose lunch. But a flip of the O2 switch back behind the left side of the seat and I was ready for more. It all went by so fast, we flew for almost an hour and it seemed like 15 minutes.


You should look into flying with the Blue Angels so you can compare and contrast the experiences, I am sure they would be happy to take you along and wear you out too.


And the walk to the plane was slow motion. I actually arrived at the airport before the planes and had to sit inside the ready room listening to them do their passes to mark landmarks for the airshow that weekend. Only 7 of the planes made it, the one I was supposed to fly in had a problem and was delayed waiting for a part to arrive. I flew with the narrator and he was a very cool guy.

It's worth mentioning that sound speed really only depends on external temperature. Yes, this does mean that sound speed will be a bit slower at higher altitude because the air is a bit colder, but the vast, vast majority of the difference in calibrated airspeed between your 20,000 foot M1 run and 30,000 foot M1 run is purely due to the density difference.

I don't know what the external temperatures were for you on that day, but using the standard atmosphere as a reference, at 20,000 feet, we would expect an external temperature of -24.6C, leading to a sound speed of 316 m/s (614 knots), while at 30,000 feet, we would expect -44.4C external temperature and a sound speed of 303 m/s (589 knots). Note that both of these are far greater than your indicated 491 and 392 knots, and also much closer together - this is because calibrated airspeed is more a measure of dynamic pressure than it is actually a measurement of speed.

Calibrated airspeed is basically telling you the speed which you would have to go at sea level to get the same dynamic pressure as you are currently experiencing. This means that at sea level, it's very close to correct, but up at 40,000 feet, where density is 1/4 of sea level, your calibrated airspeed will be ~half of what your true airspeed is.

This of course is a very useful measurement when flying, since it tells you a lot about what your acceptable load factors are, how close you are to stalling, etc, but it is fairly useless when talking about how sound speed varies with altitude, since CAS varies far more with altitude than sound speed does.

I would imagine you're already familiar with this, given your clearly well-loved copy of Anderson's Fundamentals of Aerodynamics that you show at the beginning, but in the video, this seemed very unclear to me (and it is a common misconception that sound speed depends on density or pressure of air, when in reality temperature is the only relevant variable, at least for conditions where it approximates an ideal gas).

(I'm also glossing over a few of the complications of calibrated airspeed here, since really what I'm describing above is closer to indicated airspeed rather than calibrated, but that doesn't really matter for my point here)

• 15:55 - Naturally. The atmosphere is thinner at higher altitudes, so there are fewer particles to propagate sound, making the speed of sound lower, and thus able to be broken at a lower speed.
• 19:55 - Been there; not with a jet, but in other situations. We might feel we're tough and can power through things with shear mental fortitude, but our bodies say, "hold my coffee". (Dehydration is a lot more horrible than you'd think. 😬)
• 21:49 - That's nystagmus (tracking eye movements). Your ear has tiny calcium crystals called otoliths that float in the fluid in the utricles that stimulate cilia which connect to nerves and is how your vestibule system provides proprioception. Spinning around like that causes the otoliths to slosh through the fluid hard enough that they keep moving for a little while after you've stopped, causing your brain to think you're still moving, and thus move your eyes to try to gain a fix on the world. You probably felt dizzy and nauseous. If you're unlucky, you might get a case of BPPV (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo) where some (or even just one) otolith may get dislodged and float around loose, causing you to feel like that all the time. If you're lucky, it'll resolve in a few days; if not, you may feel like you just got off the Vomitron all the time. :-\

Destin,

What a great video! It's been a long time since I've flown a fighter and I can remember how difficult it was for me to be comfortable at high G's. The hardest thing I had to learn was to fly while looking backwards. In an air-to-air sortie, you spend half the time on the defensive. In the F4, my first fighter, you had a couple of handles on the canopy rail that you could grab to twist your body around. In the Viper you don't have those handles so you needed super human strength to look over the tail of the jet whilst pulling G's and performing evasive maneuvers against someone trying to put bullets in your neck.

Whenever I'm at an airshow people are always in awe of how cool it looks on the ground. Now, you know that the view inside the cockpit is even better. Welcome to the club!

-Boz

There's all sorts of things to unpack from this video, but one thing you glossed over that I found really interesting with modern fighter craft: The nimbleness. You mentioned the aircraft's response, but what a lot of people don't know is that it comes at the cost of stability. Think of Speed, Agility, and Stability the three corners to an aircraft's aerodynamic design. You can increase one corner of the pyramid, but you pay for it by one or both of the other sides. Commercial aircraft (like the Boeing 7X7 series or the Airbus A3XX series) focus on speed and stability over agility. This means those aircraft have a wide flight profile before you've exceeded the characteristics of the plane and it loses lift and drops from the sky. This also means that they tend to maneuver like a lead duck. Fighter jets are actually described as "aerodynamically unstable". They favor speed and agility by sacrificing stability. They have a very narrow flight envelope that will quickly turn that plane into the world's fastest brick. This is common among all modern jet fighters, but planes like the F-111 were especially known for this. To counter this, they rely on fly by wire systems to take the pilot's input and adjust the flight control surfaces to keep the aircraft within it's flight envelope. (Commercial aircraft use fly by wire systems, but more like power steering in a car because of the forces acting on the control surfaces.)

Talking about the disorientation you feel through your inner ear, when you're learning how to fly a plane some of the training you go through is to teach you to trust your instruments. The instructor will have you close your eyes, or cover them, and then set the aircraft in at a weird angle and tell you to right it based just off of feel. You learn very quickly that what you feel isn't true and that when you're caught in a situation with zero visibility your instruments will guide you through.
